questions.neutral: You look like you dodged something - true?

hobby.message: Origami's still better than meds, huh?
That camera still your favorite weapon?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Maybe. It's been a tense week, everyone looks over their shoulder.
I make origami—fold paper, intricate patterns. Helps—sometimes.
My hobby doesn't cause trouble. Just keeps my mind from spiraling.
You’re not wrong. Some days, safe means quiet corners.
I fold origami. Patterns help me focus, especially lately.
Difficult to find paper when supplies are tight after outages.
The city’s noise makes simple things complicated.
Probably. Things have shifted since the tribunal fallout.
Origami is my thing. I make cranes, tessellations—sometimes full modulars.
The recent blackout forced me to finish one in the dark.
Paper is hard to come by, but it matters to me.
It’s strange, folding when the world outside is falling apart.
I find clarity in the patterns, even if nothing else makes sense.
More like sidestepped a landslide. It’s been… unpredictable since the broadcasts.
I make origami—complicated designs, not just cranes. Layers, tessellations, abstract forms.
When the power failed last week, I finished a model just by feel.
People call folding childish. It isn’t. It’s controlled complexity, not chaos.
The shortages since the tribunal make it harder, but I ration paper anyway.
Some nights, folding is the only thing that keeps my anxiety manageable.
I keep my models hidden. Even a hobby can raise questions lately.
Ducking trouble feels second nature after this month. The tribunal put a spotlight on everyone, me included.
Origami is my outlet. I fold elaborate tessellations—modular polyhedra, insects, never just simple cranes.
Paper’s almost contraband with the shortages. I salvage old forms, official notices—sometimes even tribunal documents no one will miss.
During the blackout, finishing a folding cycle by lamplight felt… like reclaiming something normal.
Most people think it’s pointless. But for me, origami is pattern and predictability—not at all like living with a variable BCI.
After the tribunal, neighbors whispered about ‘snitches’ and ‘heroes.’ I just kept folding. Quiet action is the only place I still have control.
I hide my models in plain sight now, mostly out of defiance, maybe habit.
Funny—these days, every crease feels like its own kind of resistance.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still origami.
Just helps to keep busy, you know.
Materials are harder to find. Blackout interrupted a piece.
That’s all.
It is. Safer than politics.
I just needed something quiet after the tribunal.
Paper’s short supply now—people hoarding everything.
Lights cut mid-fold yesterday. Lost my place.
Trying to keep routine.
Yes, still folding cranes and tessellations.
It’s better than thinking about the BCI half the time.
Blackout last night nearly ruined my latest model.
You can’t concentrate with people yelling about restitution in the hallway.
Still, it gives me a pattern I can finish.
At least that’s within my control.
Helps push out everything else.
Yeah, definitely still my shield.
Folding paper helps me block out BCI nightmares.
That blackout pushed me to finish a crane by candlelight.
Voices outside quoting my testimony—almost broke my focus.
Paper’s scarce, but routine matters now more than ever.
Each fold felt deliberate, like proof I could create something stable.
Right now, even that small control is resistance.
Origami never judges, never rewrites outcomes.
Always my shield. Origami’s been habit since I started at Directorate.
After testifying, I folded a crane with shaking hands—paper’s from old ledger sheets.
When the blackout hit, I kept going. Candles, creased edges—I wanted it finished no matter what.
You can’t hide from your public role, but you can still finish a fold.
Heard my own name in the stairwell—familiar and strange.
The process calms me even now, when BCI’s errors keep me up.
People hoard paper, fear new shortages, and yet I keep scavenging.
Sometimes I think the system fears unused potential—origami is proof of something else.
Making something out of scrap helps, especially when trust in everything else breaks.
